meanings.sent1: She tried to windle her friend into believing a made-up story.
meanings.sent2: The magician used sleight of hand to windle the audience during the show.
meanings.sent3: The mischievous cat tried to windle the dog by hiding its toy.
meanings.sent4: The con artist was known to windle unsuspecting victims out of their money.
meanings.sent5: His smooth talk and charming smile helped him windle many people into buying his products.

meanings.definition: To dwindle or decrease in size or amount.
meanings.sent1: The water level in the pond began to windle after a long dry spell.
meanings.sent2: As the days passed, the food supplies in the bunker started to windle.
meanings.sent3: The number of cookies in the jar continued to windle as the children snacked.
meanings.sent4: Her patience began to windle as she waited for the delayed train.
meanings.sent5: The sunlight started to windle as the storm clouds rolled in.
